image_1.context: San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York and Across U.S., It’s Getting Harder to Find a Home Hershel Williams, known as Woody, the last surviving Medal of Honor recipient from World War II, lay in honor at the U.S. Capitol on Thursday. image_1.description: The image is a close-up photograph of a dollop of mustard, likely Dijon mustard given its smooth texture and vibrant yellow color. The mustard is spread out on a surface, possibly a piece of paper or a light-colored background, with a slightly irregular shape that suggests it has been recently applied or smeared. The context provided in the surrounding text discusses the importance of mustard, particularly Dijon mustard, in French cuisine and the challenges faced due to its scarcity. The text mentions alternatives such as horseradish, wasabi, Worcestershire sauce, and creams of Roquefort or shallots, but emphasizes the irreplaceability of Dijon mustard in various dishes and sauces.

image_2.context: “It’s like Today more families in the middle of America who could once count on becoming homeowners can’t be so confident anymore. And communities that long relied on their relatively affordable housing to draw new residents can no longer be so sure of that advantage. What once seemed a blue-state coastal problem has increasingly become a national one, with consequences for the quality of life of American families, the health of the national economy and the politics of housing construction. with Appleton, Wis., and Naples, Fla. Soaring Prices Threaten Further Disruption to the Economy By EMILY BADGER and EVE WASHINGTON  braved machine-gun fire to break through the Japanese defenses on Iwo Jima. He was 98. Across U.S., It’s Getting Harder to Find a Home San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York and Washington have long failed to build enough housing to keep up with everyone trying to live there. And for nearly as long, other parts of the country have mostly been able to shrug off the housing shortage as a condition particular to big coastal cities. But in the years leading up to the pandemic, that condition advanced around the country: Springfield, Mo., stopped having enough housing. And the same
image_2.description: The image depicts a solemn and formal scene inside what appears to be a government building, likely the U.S. Capitol or a similar official venue. At the center of the image is a casket draped with an American flag, suggesting a state funeral or memorial service for a prominent figure. The casket is placed on a platform covered with black cloth and surrounded by floral arrangements. To the left of the casket stands a uniformed officer, possibly a member of the military or police, in a stance of respect and vigilance. The background features a large painting depicting historical figures, adding to the solemnity and significance of the setting. The floor is highly polished marble, reflecting the various elements of the scene. Gold stanchions with red velvet ropes create a barrier around the casket, guiding visitors and maintaining a respectful distance. In the foreground, blurred figures are seen moving, indicating the presence of mourners or officials paying their respects. The overall atmosphere is one of reverence and somberness, befitting a high-profile memorial service.

caption: Note: Shortage percentages reflect estimated housing units needed to meet demand, as a share of existing housing units. Source: Up for Growth analysis of U.S. Census Bureau and U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development data.

image_3.description: The image is a choropleth map of the United States, illustrating the housing shortage or surplus across different counties. The map uses a color gradient to represent the percentage of housing units needed to meet demand as a share of existing housing units. The color scale ranges from yellow to purple, with yellow indicating a housing shortage (negative percentages) and purple indicating a housing surplus (positive percentages). The percentages are marked on the scale from -6% to +6%. Notable observations include significant housing shortages in areas such as California, Nevada, and parts of Colorado, indicated by darker shades of yellow. In contrast, areas with housing surpluses, shown in shades of purple, are more prevalent in the Midwest and parts of the Northeast. Specific states like Illinois, Indiana, and parts of Texas also show varying degrees of housing surplus. The map provides a visual representation of the housing market dynamics across the United States, highlighting regions where demand exceeds supply and vice versa.

image_4.description: The image is a black and white photograph of two individuals dressed in formal attire. The person on the left is a woman with voluminous, styled blonde hair. She is wearing a white blouse adorned with black polka dots and a matching necklace. Her makeup is notable, with prominent eyeliner and red lipstick. The person on the right is a man with short, dark hair. He is dressed in a classic black tuxedo with a white shirt and a black bow tie. Both individuals are standing close to each other, facing forward, and appear to be at a formal event or gathering. The background is dark and indistinct, which emphasizes the subjects in the foreground. The overall atmosphere conveyed by the image is one of elegance and formality.

image_6.description: The image depicts an art installation with a central focus on a large, bold text that reads 'I am' and 'I hate' in white letters against a red background. The text is prominently displayed in the center of the image. Surrounding this central text are multiple smaller images arranged in a grid pattern along the walls of what appears to be an art gallery or exhibition space. Each of these smaller images features a hand gesture with the index finger pointing upwards, set against a backdrop filled with various texts and symbols in black and white. The overall color scheme of the installation is dominated by red, black, and white. The atmosphere conveyed is one of strong emotional impact and social commentary, likely related to themes of identity and expression. The gallery space itself is modern and minimalistic, with clean lines and a bright, well-lit environment.
